content.text: One of the most important skills in quantificational logic is understanding how negation interacts with quantifiers. The key insight: negating a universal gives you an existential, and vice versa.

content.definition: ¬∀x(P(x)) is equivalent to ∃x(¬P(x)). 'Not everything has P' means the same as 'Something lacks P'.
¬∃x(P(x)) is equivalent to ∀x(¬P(x)). 'Nothing has P' means the same as 'Everything lacks P'.

content.title: Quantifier Negation Examples
premises: Not all students passed → Some student didn't pass
No dogs fly → All dogs don't fly
content.note: These equivalences are fundamental. When you push negation past a quantifier, the quantifier flips (∀ ↔ ∃) and the negation moves inside.

content.text: **'No' statements**: 'No A is B' means 'It's not the case that some A is B', which translates as ¬∃x(A(x) ∧ B(x)), or equivalently ∀x(A(x) → ¬B(x)).

content.question: What is ¬∀x(P(x)) equivalent to?
content.explanation: Negating a universal quantifier flips it to existential and moves the negation inside: ¬∀x(P(x)) ≡ ∃x(¬P(x)). 'Not everything is P' means 'Something is not P'.
